entity1.name: Forensic Science
entity1.description: The application of scientific methods and techniques to solve crimes and legal issues.

entity2.name: Crimes
entity2.description: Actions that are prohibited by law and punishable by the state or other authority.

entity3.name: Legal Issues
entity3.description: Disputes or problems that involve legal rights, obligations, or responsibilities.

entity4.name: forensic science
entity4.description: A field of study that applies scientific principles to the examination and analysis of physical evidence for legal purposes.

entity5.name: biology
entity5.description: The natural science concerned with the study of living organisms and their processes.

entity6.name: chemistry
entity6.description: The branch of science that deals with the identification of the substances of which matter is composed; the investigation of their properties and the ways they interact, combine, and change.

entity7.name: physics
entity7.description: The natural science that involves the study of matter, its motion, and behavior through space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force.

entity8.name: mathematics
entity8.description: The abstract science of number, quantity, and space, either as abstract concepts (pure mathematics) or as applied to other disciplines such as physics and engineering (applied mathematics).

entity9.name: forensic science
entity9.description: A scientific discipline that applies scientific methods to the examination and analysis of physical evidence in legal matters.

entity10.name: fingerprint
entity10.description: A mark made by the friction ridges of the skin on a finger, often used in criminal investigations for identification purposes.

entity11.name: DNA sample
entity11.description: A specimen taken from an individual's body that contains genetic material, used to establish identity or relationship in legal and medical contexts.

entity12.name: firearm
entity12.description: A weapon designed to discharge projectiles at high velocity by the action of an explosive force, often used in criminal activities and investigations.

entity13.name: tool mark
entity13.description: An impression or alteration left on a surface by a tool, which can be analyzed to identify the specific tool used in a crime.

entity14.name: Forensic scientists
entity14.description: Experts who use scientific methods to solve crimes by analyzing physical evidence.

entity15.name: microscopy
entity15.description: A method of viewing objects that are too small to be seen with the naked eye using a microscope.

entity16.name: spectroscopy
entity16.description: An analytical technique used to determine the properties of materials by measuring their interaction with light or other radiation.

entity17.name: chromatography
entity17.description: A laboratory technique for separating mixtures into their individual components based on differences in chemical and physical properties.

entity18.name: DNA profiling
entity18.description: A method of identifying individuals by analyzing patterns in their DNA, often used in forensic science to solve crimes or establish paternity.

entity19.name: forensic scientists
entity19.description: Experts who use scientific methods to analyze physical evidence in criminal investigations.

entity20.name: suspect
entity20.description: An individual suspected of committing a crime, whose identity may be determined through forensic analysis.

entity21.name: cause of death
entity21.description: The reason or circumstances leading to someone's demise, which can be identified by forensic examination.

entity22.name: Forensic science
entity22.description: A scientific discipline that applies scientific methods to legal issues and criminal investigations.

entity23.name: advanced technology
entity23.description: Sophisticated tools, techniques, or processes used in various fields for improved efficiency and accuracy.

entity24.name: instrumentation
entity24.description: The use of instruments to measure and control physical quantities and processes, often used in scientific research and industrial applications.

entity25.name: forensic scientists
entity25.description: Professionals who apply scientific principles and techniques to investigate crimes.

entity26.name: scanning electron microscopes
entity26.description: A type of microscope that uses a beam of electrons to scan the surface of a specimen, producing detailed images at high magnification.

entity27.name: trace evidence
entity27.description: Small pieces of physical evidence found at a crime scene or on a person that can be used to link a suspect to the crime, such as fibers or hair.

entity28.name: fibers
entity28.description: Strands of material, often from clothing or fabric, which can be analyzed for forensic purposes.

entity29.name: hair
entity29.description: A form of biological evidence that can provide information about an individual's identity and other characteristics when analyzed forensically.

entity30.name: mass spectrometry
entity30.description: An analytical technique used to measure the mass-to-charge ratio of ions, which can be used to identify and quantify substances in a sample.

entity31.name: drugs
entity31.description: Chemical substances that can alter physiological or psychological functions when ingested or administered.

entity32.name: toxins
entity32.description: Poisonous substances, often produced by living organisms, which can cause harm to biological systems.

entity33.name: forensic analysis
entity33.description: A scientific method used to gather and examine information about past events, particularly in the context of legal or criminal investigations.

entity34.name: criminal investigations
entity34.description: The process of collecting and analyzing evidence to solve crimes and identify perpetrators.

entity35.name: forensic scientists
entity35.description: Experts who use scientific methods to analyze physical evidence and assist in criminal investigations.

entity36.name: crime scene investigation
entity36.description: The process of collecting, preserving, and analyzing evidence from a location where a crime has occurred.

entity37.name: crime scene
entity37.description: The place where a crime has occurred and which may contain evidence related to the incident.

entity38.name: forensic scientists
entity38.description: Experts who use scientific methods to collect and analyze evidence from crime scenes.

entity39.name: investigators
entity39.description: Persons responsible for conducting investigations, often in law enforcement or legal contexts.

entity40.name: forensic science
entity40.description: A scientific discipline that applies scientific methods to legal issues and investigations.

entity41.name: court
entity41.description: An institution where legal matters are heard and decided by a judge or jury.

entity42.name: law enforcement agencies
entity42.description: Organizations responsible for enforcing laws and maintaining public order.

entity43.name: lawyers
entity43.description: Professionals who practice law and represent clients in legal matters.

entity44.name: judges
entity44.description: Officials who preside over court proceedings and make decisions on legal cases.

entity45.name: Forensic scientists
entity45.description: Professionals who apply scientific methods to the investigation of crimes.

entity46.name: forensic science
entity46.description: A field of study that applies scientific principles and techniques to matters of legal importance, particularly in the investigation of crimes.

entity47.name: scientific principles
entity47.description: Fundamental truths or propositions that serve as the foundation for a system of belief or behavior.

entity48.name: investigative techniques
entity48.description: Procedures and methods used to gather information, often in the context of solving crimes or mysteries.

entity49.name: forensic scientists
entity49.description: Experts who apply scientific principles and techniques to assist in criminal investigations and legal proceedings.

entity50.name: technology
entity50.description: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry and computing.

entity51.name: forensic science
entity51.description: A scientific discipline that applies principles from natural sciences to assist in the resolution of legal issues or investigations.
